headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Aug. 27, 2011

headline: A Day in Mexico's Drug Wars
summary: Take a look at the events of July 29, 2011, and the stories of the dead.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Aug. 27, 2011

headline: Air Canada's Flight Attendants Reject Tentative Agreement
summary: Air Canada's flight attendants have given a solid thumbs-down to a tentative agreement with the airline, reached early this month.

headline: Boston Transit Calls Off Most Sunday Service
summary: The mass transit agency in the Boston area decided to call off service for most of Sunday due to Hurricane Irene, despite earlier hopes to keep trains and buses rolling through the storm.

headline: Lagarde: Economy in 'Dangerous Phase'
summary: Risks to the global economy are rising and countries must be quick in adopting the right policy mix to ensure a continued recovery, International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde said.

headline: Storm Barriers Likely to Close in New England
summary: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is likely to close hurricane barriers near Providence, R.I., Bridgeport, Conn., and New Bedford, Mass., on Sunday morning between 3 am and 4 am eastern time, a spokesman for the Corps of Engineers said Saturday.

headline: Rebels Extend Fight to Tripoli Suburbs
summary: The rebel-led Tripoli brigade launched a fresh offensive in a southern suburb, mopping up pockets of pro-Gadhafi fighters who are believed to have retreated there after a three-day battle for control of the international airport.

headline: Springfield, Mass. Locals Head for Shelters
summary: With Irene advancing, locals carrying overnight bags began arriving at a shelter that opened in a gymnasium at Greenleaf Park.

headline: Al Qaeda's No. 2 Killed in Pakistan
summary: A U.S. drone strike killed al Qaeda's no. 2 leader earlier this week in Pakistan, in the biggest blow to the network since Osama bin Laden's death in May, officials said.

headline: Atlantic City Evacuation Tasks Jersey Leadership
summary: The Atlantic City evacuation ahead of Hurricane Irene has challenged New Jersey officials

headline: Exchanges Weigh Post-Storm Actions
summary: Exchanges were holding discussions with their regulators and trading customers Saturday as Hurricane Irene bore down on New York City and the financial services industry put emergency response plans into action.

headline: Hurricane Hits East Coast
summary: Irene slammed into North Carolina early Saturday, threatening to wreak havoc along a densely populated corridor stretching from the Mid-Atlantic through New England.

headline: Race for Japan Prime Minister Begins
summary: The race to pick Japan's next prime minister kicked off with the front-runners showing more similarities than differences in their policy platforms.

headline: Bernanke Puts Ball in Politicians' Court
summary: What the Federal Reserve chairman didn't say in his Jackson Hole speech was more telling than what he did say.

headline: Traders Think Volatility Will Be on the Decline
summary: The VIX, a leading barometer for market sentiment, deflated Friday as stocks rallied and investors unwound protective hedges after comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke.

headline: Fresh Picks From the New York Gift Fair
summary: Eleanor Pritchard's cozy blankets, portable gardens and Alessi's ingenious housewares.

headline: Job Market Still Looks Weak
summary: More people applied for unemployment benefits last week, an unexpected gain fueled in part by a labor dispute at Verizon.

headline: New York Runners Descend on Daegu
summary: While it's been a rough year so far for New York's profile in elite track, New York-trained hopefuls are heading to the world championships.

summary: The tennis champ chats about spy novels, shoes and the shot her opponents should watch out for at the U.S. Open.

headline: Freedom Doesn't Mean an Absence of Responsible Values
summary: Rabbi Jonathan Sacks talks about the recent upheavals and lawlessness in London and other Western societies and traces the cause back 50 years to the abandonment of religion ("Reversing the Decay of London Undone," Review, Aug. 20).

headline: Prime-Minister Hopefuls Skirt Nuclear Issue
summary: As many as five lawmakers are expected to enter the race to succeed Japanese Prime Minister Naoto Kan, but the hot-button issue of nuclear power is barely being discussed by the contenders.

headline: Bubbly Gold Might Take a Bath
summary: This search for the greater fool is characteristic of bubbles. Yet gold having accelerated this year, the question of whether it is now too expensive takes on new urgency.

summary: China's newest athletic star isn't shy about her non-Communist motivations.

summary: New York City readied its vast mass-transit system for Hurricane Irene's impact, putting in motion a plan to stop running buses and trains Saturday afternoon in a city where more than half of households don't own a car.

headline: Sending Your CDs to Cloud Heaven

headline: Stop Bad Behavior Without Inflicting Unjust Damage
summary: Regarding Peter Berkowitz's "College Rape Accusations and the Presumption of Male Guilt" (op-ed, Aug. 20): Whatever one feels about the prevailing responses toward sexual harassment on college campuses, Peter Berkowitz's editorial surely misses the mark.

headline: Treasury Rally Eases
summary: Treasury bonds ended on a high note, though their session strength was tempered by a U.S. stock rally following measured comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke.

summary: Maria Sharapova toasted her Fall 2011 collection for Cole Haan Thursday at the company's Soho store.

summary: It is the smell of the place that hits first when you walk in Desnuda, a slim, dark bar off Tompkins Square Park: Sweet, deeply vegetal.

summary: Gelato-filled bonbons, Vikas Khanna's Indian cookbook, Mark Bitterman's exotic salt crystals.

headline: Score Sheet

summary: Some courses are closing in on 8,000 yards for top events. How long is too long?

summary: For a moment, while I was reading Chetan Ahya's "India's Economy Is Souring, Too" (op-ed, Aug. 23), I lost my focus and thought he was writing about the United States, especially when he talked about "government bumbling," but I snapped back to reality when he talked about "lack of regulatory progress."

headline: Non-Tiger Mother Pleads for Sanity
summary: As a child of the 1970s, I was relieved to learn that another mother shares my attitude toward raising children ("A Long Summer for 'Weary Tiger' Mothers," Review, Aug. 20).

summary: An agriculture advisory firm forecast the U.S. corn crop well below federal expectations, raising concerns the coming harvest won't replenish already tight inventories.

headline: Massachusetts City Faces Another Body Blow

summary: U.S. and international airlines started canceling flights to and from New England, New York and Washington, marking the beginning of what was expected to be a widespread service shut down.

headline: Ideas Calendar: Aug. 27-Sept. 2
summary: The Melbourne Writers Festival, Toronto's Word11 blogging festival, the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society Conference and the Venice Film Festival.

headline: Corn, Off the Cob
summary: None

headline: Irene Blows Away the Final Round at the Barclays
summary: The 54-hole scorecards will determine FedEx Cup standings—if they even get that far. Plus, Fred Couples taps Tiger Woods for the Presidents Cup team, calling him "the best player in the world forever."

headline: Travers May Reveal Year's Top Horse

headline: Fare Weather for Cabbies
